title: Stefanos Kapino
text:
Stefanos Kapino (, born 18 March 1994) is a Greek professional <a href="association%20football">footballer</a> who plays as a <a href="Goalkeeper%20%28association%20football%29">goalkeeper</a> for <a href="Bundesliga">Bundesliga</a> club <a href="Arminia%20Bielefeld">Arminia Bielefeld</a> and the <a href="Greece%20national%20football%20team">Greece national team</a>.
Early life.
Stefanos was born in <a href="Piraeus">Piraeus</a> to a family who came from <a href="Albania">Albania</a>. He began playing football in the <a href="youth%20system">youth system</a> of the amateur club "Aetos" based in <a href="Korydallos">Korydallos</a>, <a href="Piraeus%20%28regional%20unit%29">Piraeus</a>. Although he was firstly approached by <a href="Olympiacos%20F.C.">Olympiacos</a> scouts, and even trained with the team for two and a half months, <a href="Panathinaikos%20F.C.">Panathinaikos</a> were the ones to secure his signature in June 2007 for a fee of .
At Panathinaikos, he gradually established himself as a member of the <a href="starting%20lineup">starting lineup</a> for the club's under-18 and under-21 teams.
Club career.
Panathinaikos.
On 17 September 2011, during a <a href="2011%E2%80%9312%20Superleague%20Greece">Super League</a> match against <a href="Atromitos%20F.C.">Atromitos</a>, Kapino made his debut for <a href="Panathinaikos%20F.C.">Panathinaikos</a>' men's team, coming on as a substitute after his teammate <a href="Orestis%20Karnezis">Orestis Karnezis</a> was sent off. With that appearance, he became the youngest goalkeeper to ever play for Panathinaikos, at the age of 17 years, six months and nine days. He went on to play the following 11 matches, finishing his first season with 12 appearances.
The 2012–13 season saw Panathinaikos use four different managers – <a href="Jesualdo%20Ferreira">Jesualdo Ferreira</a>, the Argentine <a href="Juan%20Ram%C3%B3n%20Rocha">Juan Ramón Rocha</a>, Spanish <a href="Fabriciano%20Gonz%C3%A1lez">Fabri</a> and finally <a href="Giannis%20Vonortas">Giannis Vonortas</a> – while the club finished sixth in the league. Kapino was limited to one appearances, in a home 3–2 win against <a href="Veria%20F.C.">Veria</a>.
In summer 2013 he was linked with <a href="Arsenal%20F.C.">Arsenal</a>, <a href="Inter%20Milan">Inter Milan</a> and <a href="Manchester%20United%20F.C.">Manchester United</a> and it was reported a move to <a href="S.S.C.%20Napoli">Napoli</a> had broken down. The <a href="2013%E2%80%9314%20Superleague%20Greece">2013–14 season</a> proved to be Kapino's best season at Panathinaikos. He started as regular to most of the Super League games and as a consequence was selected for the final squad of the <a href="2014%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">2014 World Cup</a>.
Mainz 05.
In 2014, Kapino moved to German <a href="Bundesliga">Bundesliga</a> side <a href="1.%20FSV%20Mainz%2005">Mainz 05</a> for a transfer fee of reportedly €2.2 million and signed a four-year contract until 2018. He had to compete with <a href="Loris%20Karius">Loris Karius</a> for a spot in the starting grid. He made his Bundesliga debut on 7 February 2015 at home versus <a href="Hertha%20BSC">Hertha BSC</a> as a 34th minute replacement for <a href="Christian%20Clemens">Christian Clemens</a> after the starting goalkeeper Loris Karius was given a red card for a foul on the last man.
Olympiacos.
After one year with Mainz, during which he could not establish himself, Kapino moved back to his native Greece to join <a href="Olympiacos%20F.C.">Olympiacos</a>, rivals of his former club Panathinaikos, on a three-year deal for a transfer of believed to be €2 million.
He made his <a href="Super%20League%20Greece">Greek Super League</a> debut for Olympiacos on 21 March 2016 away to <a href="Asteras%20Tripoli%20F.C.">Asteras Tripolis</a>. He was part of the starting XI of the squad in the <a href="2015%E2%80%9316%20Greek%20Football%20Cup">2015–16 Greek Football Cup</a> season, except in the final where Olympiacos were defeated by rivals <a href="AEK%20Athens%20F.C.">AEK Athens</a> in an empty <a href="Olympic%20Stadium%20%28Athens%29">Olympic Stadium</a>.
On 27 July 2016, Kapino made his first European appearance with the club in the 3rd qualifying round of <a href="UEFA%20Champions%20League">UEFA Champions League</a> against the <a href="2015%E2%80%9316%20Israeli%20Premier%20League">Israeli champions</a> <a href="Hapoel%20Be%27er%20Sheva%20F.C.">Hapoel Be'er Sheva</a> He started the <a href="2016%E2%80%9317%20Superleague%20Greece">2016–17 season</a> as the indisputable first goalkeeper of the club. On 6 November 2016, he suffered a muscular injury during the second half of the 3–0 home win in the <a href="List%20of%20sports%20rivalries">derby</a> against Panathinaikos and was substituted by <a href="Nicola%20Leali">Nicola Leali</a>. The injury would keep him on the sidelines for three to four weeks ruling him out of the Greece squad to face <a href="Belarus%20national%20football%20team">Belarus</a> and <a href="Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina%20national%20football%20team">Bosnia</a>.
On 19 March 2017, Kapino returned to action following his replacement Leali's mistakes in two <a href="UEFA%20Europa%20League">Europa League</a> matches against <a href="Be%C5%9Fikta%C5%9F%20J.K.">Besiktas</a>
making saves that prevented a bigger defeat for Olympiacos in an away 1–0 derby loss against rivals Panathinaikos.
He started the <a href="2017%E2%80%9318%20Superleague%20Greece">2017–18 season</a> as the undisputed first goalkeeper of the club, despite the acquisition of ex-Belgian international <a href="Silvio%20Proto">Silvio Proto</a>.
On 24 September 2017, Kapino was demoted to the club's U-20 squad ahead of an important <a href="UEFA%20Champions%20League">UEFA Champions League</a> game against <a href="Juventus%20F.C.">Juventus</a> following mistakes in the team's 3–2 Super League away loss against rivals <a href="AEK%20Athens%20F.C.">AEK Athens</a> after leading 0–2. This proved to be the last league game for Kapino who, after also appearing and underperforming in two <a href="Greek%20Football%20Cup">Greek Cup</a> fixtures, was put on the out-of-favour player list by Olympiacos on 4 December 2017. He was unable to find a club to continue his career after the end of the January 2018 transfer window, leading the Olympiacos board to the termination of his contract and his release on a free transfer.
Nottingham Forest.
On 7 February 2018, days before the end of the transfer window for unattached players, Kapino signed with <a href="EFL%20Championship">EFL Championship</a> side <a href="Nottingham%20Forest%20F.C.">Nottingham Forest</a>, under the presidency of chairman <a href="Evangelos%20Marinakis">Evangelos Marinakis</a>, on an 18-month deal. On 21 April 2018, he made his debut with the club as a starter, in a 2–1 away loss against <a href="Cardiff%20City%20F.C.">Cardiff City</a>.
Werder Bremen.
On 1 August 2018, Kapino joined <a href="Bundesliga">Bundesliga</a> side <a href="SV%20Werder%20Bremen">Werder Bremen</a> for an undisclosed fee. According to media reports, he signed a contract until 2020 with an option of a further year while the transfer fee paid to Nottingham Forest was estimated at €300,000 which could rise up to €1 million depending on bonuses. A week later, he suffered an injury which could rule him out for three months. On 19 January 2019, he sat on the bench for the first time in a 1–0 home win against <a href="Hannover%2096">Hannover 96</a>. On 13 April 2019, he made his debut with the club replacing the injured <a href="Ji%C5%99%C3%AD%20Pavlenka">Jiří Pavlenka</a> in the second half of a 2–1 Bundesliga home win game against <a href="SC%20Freiburg">SC Freiburg</a>.
In July 2019, Kapino agreed a contract extension with the club. On 7 March 2019, almost a year since his last appearance as a starter, Kapino was in the starting XI replacing Pavlenka, who had been injured midweek.
Kapino joined <a href="2.%20Bundesliga">2. Bundesliga</a> club <a href="SV%20Sandhausen">SV Sandhausen</a> on loan for the rest of the season in January 2021.
Arminia Bielefeld.
Kapino moved to <a href="Bundesliga">Bundesliga</a> club <a href="Arminia%20Bielefeld">Arminia Bielefeld</a> for an undisclosed fee in August 2021, having agreed a contract until 2023. On 18 December, after regular goalkeeper <a href="Stefan%20Ortega">Stefan Ortega</a> had to self-quarantine after testing positive to <a href="COVID-19">COVID-19</a>, Kapino played in a 2-0 away victory against <a href="RB%20Leipzig">RB Leipzig</a>, in his club effort to avoid relegation.
International career.
Kapino due to being born in Greece was eligible to represent Greece and his Albanian heritage made him eligible for Albania, and he has been a member of the <a href="Greece%20national%20under-17%20football%20team">Greece under-17</a> and <a href="Greece%20national%20under-19%20football%20team">under-19 teams</a>. He is the youngest player to ever play for Greece U17, having debuted at the age of 15.
On 15 November 2011, at the age of 17 years and 241 days, he made his debut for the <a href="Greece%20national%20football%20team">men's national team</a> in a friendly match against <a href="Romania%20national%20football%20team">Romania</a>, thus setting a new record for the youngest player ever to represent Greece at men's level.
Stefanos was member to the 23-man squad for <a href="2014%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">2014 FIFA World Cup</a> in Brazil as third choice goalkeeper along with <a href="Orestis%20Karnezis">Orestis Karnezis</a> and <a href="Panagiotis%20Glykos">Panagiotis Glykos</a>.
On 4 June 2016, Kapino came on as a first half substitute for injured first choice goalkeeper <a href="Orestis%20Karnezis">Orestis Karnezis</a> and despite conceding a late goal, produced a stunning display for his adopted country making many world class saves in Greece's 1–0 away International Friendly defeat to <a href="Australia%20national%20soccer%20team">Australia</a> at <a href="Stadium%20Australia">Stadium Australia</a> in <a href="Sydney">Sydney</a>.
On 25 March 2017, replacing injured <a href="Orestis%20Karnezis">Orestis Karnezis</a> in a crucial <a href="2018%20FIFA%20World%20Cup%20qualification">2018 FIFA World Cup qualification</a> away match against <a href="Belgium%20national%20football%20team">Belgium</a> did brilliantly throughout the game and especially at the extra time as he prevent <a href="Romelu%20Lukaku">Romelu Lukaku</a> from scoring the winner from point-blank range with a brilliant double save, helping Greece to save the defeat in its effort to qualify for <a href="2018%20World%20Cup">2018 World Cup</a>.
Honours.
Panathinaikos
Olympiacos
Greece U19
